p: Tannins are water-soluble phenols characterized by their potential to create complexes with the proteins and, to a lesser extent, with metals and ions [ 28]. Due to this chemical property, dietary tannins can have both adverse and beneficial effects on ruminants, depending on factors such as dose, chemical composition, and characteristics of the basal diet [ 29]. Regarding dairy ruminants, tannins can increase milk protein percentage and reduce urea content [ 30] by favoring the outflow of protein nitrogen from the rumen [ 31], which is one of the limiting factors for milk production.
